all_procs.sona.csv:
item,phasetype,survey,max_time,text,notes,shuffle_1,task_title,task_body_text,weight, 0,offline,,user,,,off,STUDY TEMPORARILY OFFLINE,"We're sorry but the study is currently offline as the University is conducting a major upgrade to the database used to store the experimental data.

The update is expected to take most of the night. As a result, the experiment is unlikely to be available before tomorrow morning (Wednesday 4th June).
Please try again then. We shall update this message if the upgrade takes longer than expected.",, 0,intro_static,,user,Welcome,no_mobile,off,,,, 0,zoom_check,,user,,,off,,,, 0,jans_infoconsent,,user,"Re-examining taboo, emotionally valenced, and emotionally neutral word norms",,off,,,, 0,task_bookend,,user,Start,,off,Word Ratings,"

In this study we are interested in how people perceive words. For the next task, you will be given a list of 120 words - one at a time - and your task is to rate each word according to the scales presented.

Please be as honest as possible in your judgments; they are very important to us! Work at a rapid pace and don't spend too much time on each word. Make your ratings based on your first reaction to the word.

The words are presented in four blocks of 30 words, and you will be given a break after each block.


When you are ready, please press Start to begin.

",, 2 to 31,jans_ratings,,user,,,Ratings,,,, 0,task_bookend,,user,Start Block 2,,off,Time For A Break,"

Thank you for rating the first 30 words, when you are ready please press Start Block 2 to move onto the second block of 30 words. Once again, please be as honest as possible in your judgments; they are very important to us! Work at a rapid pace and don't spend too much time on each word. Make your ratings based on your first reaction to the word.

",, 32 to 61,jans_ratings,,user,,,Ratings,,,, 0,task_bookend,,user,Start Block 3,,off,Time For A Break,"

Thank you for rating the second 30 words, when you are ready please press Start Block 3 to move onto the third block of 30 words. Once again, please be as honest as possible in your judgments; they are very important to us! Work at a rapid pace and don't spend too much time on each word. Make your ratings based on your first reaction to the word.

",, 62 to 91,jans_ratings,,user,,,Ratings,,,, 0,task_bookend,,user,Start Block 4,,off,Time For A Break,"

Thank you for rating the third 30 words, when you are ready please press Start Block 4 to move onto the final block of 30 words. Once again, please be as honest as possible in your judgments; they are very important to us! Work at a rapid pace and don't spend too much time on each word. Make your ratings based on your first reaction to the word.

",, 92 to 121,jans_ratings,,user,,,Ratings,,,, 0,task_bookend,,user,Start,,off,Individual Difference Measures,"

Thank you for completing the previous task. We are now going to ask you to complete three questionnaires. One relates to trait aggression, one to your personality, and one to trait anger. They may not be presented in that order. All answers you give are entirely anonymous and cannot be traced back to you, so please be honest in how you respond.


When you are ready, please press Start to begin.

",, 0,tde_survey,verbal_agressiveness.csv,user,60,,Questionnaire,,,, 0,tde_survey,trait_anger.csv,user,50,,Questionnaire,,,, 0,tde_survey,big_five_inventory.csv,user,60,,Questionnaire,,,, 0,task_bookend,,user,Start,,off,Religiosity & Control Measures,"

Thank you for completing the three questionnaires. We now just need you to provide two further ratings before we collect some basic demographic information. These ratings, together with your questionnaire responses and demographic details will allow us to not only understand who has taken part in our study, but also how those differences between people affects how they perceive and use swearwords.

",, 0,jans_conrelig,,user,,,off,Religiosity & Control,Please read each scale carefully before making your selection and respond as accurately as possible.,, 0,task_bookend,,user,Start,,off,Demographics,"

Thank you for making the previous two ratings. You have now completed all the experimental tasks. The last thing we require is to just collect some basic demographic information about you so we can better understand who has taken part in our study.


When you are ready, please press Start to begin.

",, 0,tde_survey,jans_demo.csv,user,50,"Phase.set_timer(function(){ Â Â Â  $("".sona_item"").attr('maxlength','8'); Â  },250);",off,,,, 0,upload_data,,12,,Uploading REDCap Markers,off,,,, 0,jans_debrief,,user,"Re-examining taboo, emotionally valenced, and emotionally neutral word norms",Sona,off,,,, 0,sona,,user,https://rdg-psychology.sona-systems.com/webstudy_credit.aspx?experiment_id=2995&credit_token=5fac1cfbc43f406b94ee5c73a3437601&survey_code=,,off,Save Data & Gain Credit,"Thank you for completing the study, we really do appreciate you taking the time to do so. Before you close the study, there are two things left to do:

(1) Save your data
If we could ask you to download your data by clicking the button below and saving it to your computer. This will ensure that, as this study was run online, if there were any issues with your data uploading to the server we can use the saved file to manually add your data to the final dataset, ensuring your time wasn't wasted and/or the results of our study impacted (and you get to see what a raw data file actually looks like!). If you haven't heard from us within one month, feel free to delete the file from your computer as it will mean everything uploaded correctly.



Note: If the button doesn't work for any reason, you can save your data by pressing Ctrl+S (Cmd+S on a Mac).

(2) Gain SONA Credit
If you received a pop-up message above about your SONA ID not being stored correctly, or there is no button below, please email c.g.dobson@pgr.reading.ac.ukÂ to let Chris know you've completed the study and he will award you your credit manually. Otherwise, simply click the button below to return to SONA and automatically receive your credit.",,

verbal_agressiveness.csv:
Verbal Aggressiveness Scale



INSTRUCTIONS: This questionnaire is concerned with how we try to get people to comply with our wishes. Please select from the options beneath each statement to indicate how often each statement is true for you personally when you try to influence other persons
1. When individuals are very stubborn, I use insults to soften their stubbornness.
Almost Never True|Rarely True|Occasionally True|Often True|Almost Always True
2. When people refuse to do a task I know is important, without good reason, I tell them they are unreasonable.
Almost Never True|Rarely True|Occasionally True|Often True|Almost Always True
3. If individuals I am trying to influence really deserve it, I attack their character.
Almost Never True|Rarely True|Occasionally True|Often True|Almost Always True
4. When people behave in ways that are in very poor taste, I insult them in order to shock them into proper behavior.
Almost Never True|Rarely True|Occasionally True|Often True|Almost Always True
5. When people simply will not budge on a matter of importance I lose my temper and say rather strong things to them.
Almost Never True|Rarely True|Occasionally True|Often True|Almost Always True
6. When individuals insult me, I get a lot of pleasure out of really telling them off.
Almost Never True|Rarely True|Occasionally True|Often True|Almost Always True
7. I like poking fun at people who do things which are very stupid in order to stimulate their intelligence.
Almost Never True|Rarely True|Occasionally True|Often True|Almost Always True
8. When people do things which are mean or cruel, I attack their character in order to help correct their behaviour.
Almost Never True|Rarely True|Occasionally True|Often True|Almost Always True
9. When nothing seems to work in trying to influence others, I yell and scream in order to get some movement from them.
Almost Never True|Rarely True|Occasionally True|Often True|Almost Always True
10. When I am not able to refute othersâ€™ positions, I try to make them feel defensive in order to weaken their positions.
Almost Never True|Rarely True|Occasionally True|Often True|Almost Always True
trait_anger.csv:
Trait Anger Scale



INSTRUCTIONS: A number of statements which people have used to describe themselves are given below. Read each statement carefully and indicate how you generally feel by selecting the appropriate response option given underneath
4. l get angry when slowed down by others' mistakes...
5. I feel annoyed when not given recognition for doing good work...
7. I say nasty things when mad...
8. It makes me furious when I am criticised in front of others...
9. I feel like hitting someone when frustrated...
10. I feel infuriated when I do a good job and get a poor evaluation...
big_five_inventory.csv:
Big Five Inventory



INSTRUCTIONS: Here are a number of characteristics that may or may not apply to you. Please select a response option to indicate the extent to which you agree or disagree with each statement. The questionnaire is divided into 4 pages, once you more to another page you cannot return to the previous page - so please ensure you are happy with your answers before moving forward.

Page 1 of 4
Disagree strongly|Disagree a little|Neither agree nor disagree|Agree a little|Agree strongly

jans_demo.csv:
Demographic Information



Please could you help us better understand the diversity and inclusivity of our participants (and thus how well our data is applicable to the general population) by completing the questions below.

Questions 1-5 are optional, you do not have to answer if you wish (please select "Prefer not to say", if that is the case). You are required, however, to answer questions 6-9, as we cannot include your data in the final dataset if you do not provide and answer to these questions.

1. Please enter your age (in years)
(the input only accepts numbers e.g., 21)
4. What is the highest level of education you have completed?
GCSEs or equivalent|A-Levels or equivalent|Undergraduate (e.g., BSc)|Postgraduate (e.g., MSc)|Doctoral degree|Other|Prefer not to say
5. What is your current employment status?
Full-time employment|Part-time employment|Unemployed/Retired/Full-time education|Prefer not to say

6. Are you a native British English Speaker
(defined as being born and raised in the UK, or moved to the UK before the age of 2)
7. Are you a student or staff member in the University of Reading's School of Psychology & Clinical Language Sciences?
